items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Digital Credentials
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://wicg.github.io/digital-identities/
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/digital-identities/blob/main/proposals/identity-credential-proposal.md (to be updated - but still mostly accurate)
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @marcoscaceres @samuelgoto
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @bvandersloot-mozilla @martinthomson

Other information

The online digital credential space is complex space with lots of pieces, lots of uncertainty still, and perhaps a set of non-standardized browser-specific design properties. I think the useful review of this API is within the larger context and how having a browser API may make things better and/or worse, and the conditions (if any) under which Mozilla would be supportive of seeing this API added to the web. One possible useful resource is this talk I gave to PING at TPAC.
items.title: Digital Credentials

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: HTML
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): whatwg/html#9373
  • Explainer URL (if available): whatwg/html#9373
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts):
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug----
  • WebKit Standards Position: WebKit/standards-positions#329

Other information

This is a request for a Mozilla standards position on the idea of adding (optional) light dismiss functionality to Dialogs.
See whatwg/html#9373 for the discussion. The current proposal is a new attribute closedby (naming TBD) with three values, allowing no close bahaviour, close watcher behaviour, or close watcher and light dismiss behaviour.
items.title: Dialog light dismiss

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: CSS Color Adjustment Module Level 1
  • Specification or proposal URL: https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-adjust-1/
  • CSSWG issue: w3c/csswg-drafts#8603
  • Proposal authors: @ogerchikov @yshalivskyy

Problem statement

Many web pages don't specify the support for light/dark color schemes using CSS "color-scheme" property or meta tags. In such a case, the used color scheme is light for scrollbars and other interactive UI elements despite the user preference set on the browser/OS level. Although the behavior is expected for elements which are part of the web content, viewport non-overlay scrollbars always stay on the side of the page and are treated by users as a part of the browser UI. The current behavior confuses users who have selected dark mode and expect viewport scrollbars to follow their choice.

Proposed solution

The proposed solution is to make the browser use the user's preferred color scheme to render the viewport scrollbars if the value of "page’s supported color schemes" is 'normal' or not specified, and the computed value of the color-scheme for the root element is 'normal'. Viewport scrollbars can be considered to be outside the web content. Therefore, the user agents should honor the user's preferred color scheme when rendering viewport scrollbars if page authors have not explicitly specified support for color schemes.

Bugs tracking this feature

Chromestatus: Used color scheme root scrollbars - Chrome Platform Status (chromestatus.com)
Chromium: Make root viewport non-overlay scrollbars follow the user's preferred color scheme by default [40259909] - Chromium

Related bugs

Mozilla Bugzilla: On some websites, the scrollbars that appear from pinch zooming are different theme than non-zoomed scrollbar
items.title: [css-color-adjust-1] Root non-overlay scrollbars used color scheme

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Side Panel
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): WICG proposal WICG/proposals#123
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/SidePanel/explainer.md
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @benjycui
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

Modern browsers have a side panel that can be used to display additional information about the current page or provides a way to browse side-by-side. This proposal aims to standardize the side panel and its API. The new side panel API will allow developers to declare support for the side panel and to control their web content in the side panel.
items.title: Side Panel

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: line-clamp CSS property (collapse variant)
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): w3c/csswg-drafts#7708
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/line-clamp/README.md
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @emilio, @bfgeek, @frivoal
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio

Other information

CSS Overflow Level 4 defines line-clamp based on fragmentation (https://drafts.csswg.org/css-overflow-4/#line-clamp), but that is not feasible for Gecko to implement anytime soon. Due to that, @emilio opened w3c/csswg-drafts#7708 to discuss a variant of line-clamp that is based on hiding lines and boxes from paint instead ("the collapse variant"). There is no spec text written for this variant yet, but the CSSWG decided to greenlight both variants for prototyping, and in Chromium we are currently planning to prototype it, rather than the fragmentation-based variant.
items.title: `line-clamp` CSS property (collapse variant)

items.content_html:
Without a label on the left-hand column, it's not completely obvious that the expand button operates the way it does. Also, the fact that we add another column is surprising when you are using a screen reader - the new content tends not to be presented automatically as a result.

We could experiment with <details> here, but the fact that we have a table makes that somewhat difficult to get visual styling right.
items.title: Try to improve a11y of our dashboard

Other information

This API provides a mechanism for imposing a brightness limit on HDR content. This has been frequently requested by image gallery apps.
items.title: CSS dynamic-range-limit property
